issues.text: whether within the meaning of s.13(2) of the Finance Act, 1950 which by s.11 thereof extended the Central Excises and Salt Act, I of 1944, to the Part B States, there was, immediately before the 1st of April 1950, in force in Part State of Travancore-Cochin, a law corresponding to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-In this group of five appeals the principal question which falls to be determined is whether within the meaning of s 13 2 of the Finance Act, 1950  which by s. 11 thereof extended the Central Excise Salt Act, I of 1944, to the Part b States , there was, immediately before the 1st of April 1950, in force in Part State of Travancore-Cochin, a law Corresponding to the Central Excise Salt Act, 1944

If the effect of s. 13 2  of the Finance Act, 1950, was to repeal the Cochin Act as well as the similar Travancore Act, from April 1, 1950, there will be numberlaw in operation which would justify the framing of the new Rules either in August 1950 orin January 1951

arguments.claim: Cochin Act stood repealed by Finance Act 1950 on introduction of Central Act from April 1, 1950, making notifications framing new rules ab initio void

anchor.surface_text: The main contention raised on their behalf in their petitions was that the Cochin Act stood repealed by the Finance Act 1950, on the introduction of the Central Act in the part State of Travancore- Cochin from April 1, 1950 in consequence, the notification which was issued on August 3, 1950, or on January 25, 1951, framing new Rules for the issue of licences and prescribing rules therefor under the powers conferred under the Cochin Act or the similar Travancore Act were ab initio void, because the Acts under which the notifications were purported to be issued stood repealed from April 1, 1950.

arguments.claim: Where Act repealed provides substantially for all matters contained in repealing Act, there is correspondence and earlier Act repealed; no need for complete identity

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in The Custodian of Evacuee Property v. Khan Saheb Abdul Shakoor, etc. that where the Act repealed provides substantially for all matters contained in the Act effecting the repeal there is correspondence between the two Acts and the earlier Act would thus stand repealed it is not necessary that there should be complete identity between the repealing Act and the Act repealed in every respect.

arguments.claim: Cochin Act substantially provides for same matters as Central Act: control from cultivation to retail sale

anchor.surface_text: We have also seen that the Cochin Act similarly provides for control- on tobacco from the stage at which it is grows to the stage tillit reaches Glass licensees who sell it in retail to the consumers. The Cochin Rules may not be so detailed as the Rules under the Central Act but their main object and purpose is the same, namely, to keep a check on tobacco from the time it is grown to the time it reaches the a Glass licensee who eventually sells it to the consumer.

arguments.claim: Central Act provisions (s3 levy, s6 licences) ancillary to excise levy; similar to state controls

anchor.surface_text: The Central Act provides by s. 3 for the levy and collection of duties of excise on all excisable goods other than salt which are produced or manufactured in India Further s. 6 of the central Act gives power to the central Government to issue licences and prohibits any person from engaging in the wholesale purchase or also whether on his own account or as a broker or commission agent or the storage of any excisable goods

arguments.claim: Corresponding law if dealing with same subject matter causing duplication/overlapping, even if not identical

anchor.surface_text: The expression corresponding does not postulate identity of the State Law and the statute extended by s. 11 of the Finance Act if there was in force at the material time law in the Part B State dealing with a particular subject matter and the law extended by s. 11 of the Finance Act, 1950, dealt with the same subject matter and the two laws though not identical still were such that if they stood together there would have been legislative duplication or overlapping, the law in force in Part B State would be regarded as corresponding to the law extended by the Indian Finance Act and hence repealed by the operation of s. 13 2

arguments.claim: Only licensing provisions of state Acts corresponding to Central Act s6 and rules; thus new rules invalid

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment the relevant rules made under the Travancore and the Cochin Tobacco Acts requiring licences to be taken for storage of tobacco and in force on April, 1, 1950, were law corresponding to the provisions of the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944, and the rules framed thereunder which required licences to be taken out for storage of tobacco and for payment of licence fee in respect thereof and to that extent the provisions imposing an obligation to take out licences and to pay licence fees under the Tobacco Acts of Travancor and the Cochin States were superseded

holdings.text: The Cochin Act as well as the similar Travancore Act along with the Rules corresponded to the Central Act substantially and would thus be repealed by s. 13(2) of the Finance Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It would therefore follow that the Cochin Act as well as the similar Travancore Act along with the Rules corresponded to the Central Act substantially and would thus be repealed by s. 13 2  of the Finance Act, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Acts and rules provided comprehensive control over tobacco from cultivation to retail similar to Central Act s.3 levy and s.6 licensing; auction realizes equivalent duty; applies Custodian precedent on substantial correspondence without identity.

holdings.text: The result was that the Cochin Act as well as the similar Travancore Act stood repealed from April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore when the Central Act was extended to the Part State of Travancore-Cochin by s. 11 1  of the Finance Act and the Finance Act specifically provided by s. 13 2  for the repeal of corresponding law, the result was that the Cochin Act as well as the similar Travancore Act stood repealed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.13(2) Finance Act upon finding substantial correspondence; no charging section needed as duty via rules and auction.

holdings.text: There would be no power in the State Government thereafter to frame new Rules either in August 1950 or in January 1951 for there would be no law to support the new Rules and without such law the new Rules could not impose a tax as that would clearly offend Art. 265 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-repeal, no legal basis for rule-making; tax requires authority of law per Art.265.

holdings.text: The new Rules purporting to be framed either under the Cochin Act or under the Travancore Act in August 1950 and thereafter in January 1951 were invalid ab initio and have no force and effect.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules framed under repealed Acts lack validity; declaration appropriate despite later abrogation as rules operative when petitions filed.

holdings.text: A duty of excise is a tax on goods produced or manufactured in the taxing country; generally on manufacturer/producer but can be at subsequent stages.

anchor.surface_text: It may therefore be accepted that a duty of excise is tax on goods produced or manufactured in the taking country. It may also be accepted that generally speaking the tax is on the manufacturer or the producer, though it cannot be denied that laws are to be found which impose a duty of excise at stages subsequent to the manufacture or production.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Federal Court and Privy Council precedents; auction system fits as indirect realization post-production.

holdings.text: The relevant rules made under the Travancore and the Cochin Tobacco Acts requiring licences to be taken for storage of tobacco and in force on April 1, 1950, were law corresponding to the provisions of the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944, and the rules framed thereunder which required licences to be taken out for storage of tobacco and for payment of licence fee in respect thereof and to that extent the provisions imposing an obligation to take out licences and to pay licence fees under the Tobacco Acts of Travancore and the Cochin States were superseded.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Licensing for storage/sale ancillary to excise control in both; duplication if co-existing; narrower than majority but concurs in invalidity of new rules.

holdings.text: The State of Travancore-Cochin had no authority to promulgate rules 14, 15 and 16 under the Notification issued in the Travancore-Cochin Government Gazette dated January 25, 1951, and to levy licence fee for storage of tobacco.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Supersession of corresponding licensing provisions removes basis for new state rules.

precedents.cited_proposition: primary meaning of excise duty was of a tax on articles produced or manufactured in the taxing country; laws were to be found which impose a duty of excise at stages subsequent to the manufacture or production
precedents.cited_holding: the primary meaning of excise duty was of a tax on articles produced or manufactured in the taxing country (see p. 40)

precedents.citation: Province of Madras v Messrs. Boddu Paidanna and Son 2

In the first case it was held that the primary meaning of excise duty was of a tax on articles produced or manufactured in the taxing country

precedents.case_name: Province of Madras v Boddu Paidanna and Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: duties of excise were duties levied on the manufacture or producer of the commodity taxed

precedents.citation: Governor- General in Council v. Provinces of Madras  3

anchor.surface_text: Governor- General in Council v. Provinces of Madras  3 , where the nature of a duty of excise was considered. In the first case it was held that the primary meaning of excise duty was of a tax on articles produced or manufactured in the taxing country. It was also observed in that case that it could not be denied that laws were to be found which impose a duty of excise at stages subsequent to the manufactures or production.

precedents.case_name: Governor-General in Council v Province of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: approved of the view of the Federal Court as to the nature of the duty of excise

precedents.citation: Chaturbhai.M. Patel v. The Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: Chaturbhai.M. Patel v. The Union of India  1  where the various provisions of the Central Act  including s. 6  and the rules framed thereunder were attacked on the ground that they had nothing to do with the levy and collection of duties of excise,

precedents.case_name: Chaturbhai M Patel v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: various provisions of the Central Act and the Rules made thereunder were essentially connected with levying and collection of excise duty and in its true nature and character the Central Act remained one under item 45 of List I; the method of realising duty must be left to the wisdom of the legislature; authorities are on the track of the movement of tobacco from the time it is grown to the time it is manufactured and sold in the market
precedents.cited_holding: the various provisions of the Central Act and the Rules made thereunder were essentially Connected with levying and collection of excise duty

precedents.citation: the Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit and lubricants Taxation Act, 1938

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court In the matter of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit and lubricants Taxation Act, 1938 observed at the date of the Constitution Act  Government of India Act 1935  though it seems that the word excise was not infrequently for the administration of a particular indirect tax  as salt excise or opium excise , the only kind of excise duties which were known in India by that name were duties collected from manufacturers or producers,

precedents.case_name: In re Central Provinces and Berar Sales of Motor Spirit and Lubricants Taxation Act 1938
precedents.cited_proposition: the only kind of excise duties which were known in India by that name were duties collected from manufacturers or producers, and usually payable on the issue of the excisable articles from the place of manufacture or production
precedents.cited_holding: excise duties properly so-called often to be found at the present day which are not collected at the stage of production or manufacture

precedents.citation: The Governor-General in Council v. The Province of Madras

anchor.surface_text: This view was approved by the Judicial Committee in The Governor-General in Council v. The Province of Madras An excise duty is according to the Indian Statute, a duty on the manufacture or production of goods and the duty which was levied in the States of Travancore and Cochin on the storage of tobacco cannot be regarded as a duty of excise.

precedents.case_name: Governor-General in Council v Province of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: An excise duty is according to the Indian Statute, a duty on the manufacture or production of goods
